utterances: Industry analyst Jonathan Spira at Basex Incorporated says the terrorism concerns, the low fare competition, and a challenge of expensive fuel had been good discipline for the industry.
The airlines have learned how to re-examine every cost of doing business, every peanut that goes on the plane, and they've learned to work better with their workforces.
Are these long-term lessons that they've learned, John?
Are these profits sustainable, you think?
Well, things are still a little tenuous.
You heard Spira mention airline employees.
Over the last few years, the unions have given management a lot of wage and benefit concessions to keep the companies in the air, and now they want a piece of these new profits.
American Airlines just announced $160 million worth of stock bonuses for its management executives.
There have been some protests from pilots and flight attendants.
And there's still plenty of uncertainty throughout the industry about what's going to happen to the cost of fuel, of course.
You mentioned Southwest, or we did earlier.
They have profits for this last quarter reported today.
But they usually report profits, don't they?
Tell us a little bit about your client.
I'm sure most Americans don't know who he is, but he is quite revered among the Hmong community.
Tomorrow is Election Day.
Both houses of Congress are up for grabs and the votes could become a referendum on the president as well.
It's also a big year for black candidates.
In Massachusetts, Democrat Deval Patrick could become the state's first black governor.
Tennessee could elect the South's first African-American senator since Reconstruction.
And in Maryland, Republican Michael Steele - running for Senate - could pull off an upset in a strongly Democratic state.
For more, we'll hear from NPR's Michel Martin, Audie Cornish and Allison Keyes, who've all been in the field following this contest.
We start with Allison, who told me that race is front and center in the Maryland fight between Steele and Ben Cardin, his Democratic opponent.
Cardin beat Kweisi Mfume, the former NAACP president, in the Democratic primary.
And there are a lot of African-Americans who have been telling NPR that they're kind of angry, that they feel the Democratic Party helped Ben Cardin over Kweisi Mfume in the primary.
And they're telling NPR that they are annoyed that the Democrats are once again putting up a statewide ticket that only has one African-American on it.
In fact, four years ago, there were no African-Americans on the state ticket.

And some African-Americans, particularly in Baltimore and Prince George's County, are telling me that's how the Republicans got in last time, because Michael Steele was Republican's candidate for lieutenant governor.
Kweisi Mfume himself went and wrote an op-ed saying, hey, where's the color?
True, although he did do that op-ed in the Afro-American, which was rather interesting.
He has also campaigned with Cardin, though, and Cardin has had a lot of star power.
He appeared twice within the last couple of weeks with Illinois Democrat Barack Obama.
Both Steele and Cardin had press conferences last week with prominent African-American Democrats from Prince George's County, which is predominantly African-American.
So the battle for that part of the vote is almost what's going to drive the outcome of this race.
Because the polls are showing if there is a high African-American turnout that Cardin is leading Steele by a much higher margin than the Baltimore Sun poll that just came out.
But if the black turnout is low, they're almost in a statistical tie, according to the Republicans.
Now how has Steele made inroads with, you know, the mainly Democratic black base of places like Baltimore and other parts of the state that maybe predominantly African-American?
And what I'm thinking about here is how did he brand himself in general?
He has very much not branded himself as a Republican.
His Web site doesn't say he's a Republican.
He almost never uses the word Republican when he appears.
But I have to tell you the African-Americans at the events I've seen treat him like a rock star.
They bring their kids to take pictures of him.
They introduce themselves to him.
They are proud to see him there.
Many of them said to me, listen, he's a nice guy.
He's nice-looking and he's got a lot of charisma, which is a bit different than Ben Cardin's campaign style.
He is a long-time politician, but he doesn't have the same connection with voters that Steele seems to have.
Steele, who we've interviewed here on NEWS & NOTES, is definitely something of a political rock star in his charisma, but he also holds views that may be at odds with traditional Democratic voters.
And here I'm not talking so much about race but about party lines.
Absolutely.
He's very socially conservative.
He's a former monk - Catholic monk -and still a practicing Catholic.
And he has come down against abortion.
Absolutely.
How do his views line up along party lines?
What's interesting is that even the African-Americans that tell me they disagree with him on the issues.
In fact, I spoke to a Democrat at a rally recently who said she's voting for Michael Steele basically because she's a business owner and he helped her out.
She disagrees with him on the war.
She disagrees with him on women's choice.
She disagrees with him on stem cell research.
But she feels betrayed, she said, by the Democratic Party so she's going to vote for Steele.
And she's trying to urge other African-Americans to vote for him, to send a message to the Democratic Party that they need to stop ignoring the black vote.
Allison Keyes, thank you so much.
You're welcome.
That was NPR's Allison Keyes.
From the studios of NPR West, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Cohen.
And I'm Madeline Brand.
Coming up, seeing black.
We dissect the final episode of ""The Sopranos"" with New Jersey native David Remnick, editor of the New Yorker.
First, an alleged coup against a sovereign nation.
Today in California, General Vang Pao will make his first court appearance since he was charged with trying to overthrow the government of Laos.
Thirty years ago he fought along side the U.S.
against the communists in Southeast Asia.
They lost, and thousands of Hmong rebels and fled Laos after the communists took over in 1975; many immigrated here in the U.S.
General Vang Pao was one of them, and since then he's been a leader of the Hmong community.
General Pao is accused of supporting Laotian insurgence and now the U.S.
government says he was buying weapons and plotting to attack government buildings.
If he's convicted, Pao could spend the rest of his life in jail.
We're joined now by Tom Heffelfinger.
He's a former U.S.
attorney from Minnesota who is now leading the legal team that is defending General Vang Pao.
And welcome to the program, Mr. Heffelfinger.
I'm glad to be here, thank you.
So you're client is pleading what?
My client is charged right now by complaint - has not been asked to plead, but be pleading not guilty at the appropriate time.
Pleading not guilty.
Okay.
Well, let me just float some of the allegations by you to get your response.
He's been charged of trying to overthrow a government.
Thank you.
Caterina Alberto says the people from Quifel National Resources made a lot of promises.
They said they'd pay local farmers for any land the farmers might lose; and they'd clear new land somewhere else for them.
The company promised to drill a well, which the village really needs.
Also, improvements for the school and the clinic, jobs.
So the people of Ruasse said yes.
And the national government gave Quifel National Resources the land in December of 2009.
(Through Translator) As soon as they got here with all their gear, they just went ahead and started their work.
They went into the place where people had already planted corn, banana trees and sugar cane.
In fact, she says the company plowed up crops that farmers were almost ready to harvest.
She lost about 10 acres.
None of the farmers got any money or new land.
It's still going on.
About two months ago, the company plowed up more fields.
Two men from the village take me to see the spot.
Francisco Muine Penaciaia is young and almost shaking with anger.
Vitorino Munalile is an old man and shows no emotion at all.
He's barefoot and has trouble walking across the rough, plowed ground.
(Foreign language spoken)
Here, says Penaciaia, this is where we were growing sorghum, corn, and cassava.
We were counting on these crops for food or to sell, so we'd have some money to buy food later.
(Foreign language spoken)
Do you have food to eat for the wintertime?
